metadata.title: What I learned from being An AI Startup Co-Founder and CTO | by Tianxiang (Ivan) Liu | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: What I learned from being An AI Startup Co-Founder and CTO
metadata.description: This article has been lingering in my draft folder for some time, but I believe now is the right moment to bring it to completion. As a data-driven individual with aspirations of developing…

all_paragraphs: This article has been lingering in my draft folder for some time, but I believe now is the right moment to bring it to completion. As a data-driven individual with aspirations of developing real-world AI-powered products, I have gained valuable insights from my most recent two startup ventures and wish to share them with you.

It is often overlooked that, in the development of an AI product, the machine learning model constitutes just a small portion of the technological stack. While technical proficiency is a crucial attribute for a tech co-founder, it only represents a fraction of the contributions required for a successful business.

Many founders believe that anyone with the ability to code or create an MVP is the ideal candidate for a startup’s CTO. This is especially true for AI startups, where having a CTO with AI expertise translates to more effective IP management protocols and the ability to save time and resources in searching for an AI specialist in the early stages, which can be costly.

Before embarking on the development of an innovative AI algorithm, the initial challenge that every technology co-founder will encounter is the technical selection process. This includes making decisions regarding the infrastructure, framework, and technology stack to be utilized.

Establishing the infrastructure is a crucial step in bringing your product to market. For those with a background in AI/ML or data science and limited engineering experience, this may be uncharted territory. There are several options available, including traditional on-premise services or utilizing cloud Platform as a Service (PaaS) or Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) providers.
The benefits of utilizing cloud services are substantial, including:

The three major players in the cloud services market are Amazon Web Services (AWS), Google Cloud Platform (GCP), and Microsoft Azure. Based on personal experience, the author has utilized both AWS and GCP, and will use these as examples in the following discussion.

While the infrastructure offered by different cloud providers is generally similar, AWS is more mature and widely adopted in certain industries compared to GCP. Myself has been asked multiple times why we chose GCP as the primary cloud service provider.

It’s important to note that each startup is unique and the technology selection should be based on the specific business proposition and use cases. A tech co-founder must make informed decisions to choose the appropriate technology for their business.

Once the infrastructure is in place, the next critical step is the design of the platform architecture. It is crucial to consider various high-level aspects such as security, scalability, reliability, etc. From my experience in two startups, I have learned the importance of maintaining simplicity in the architecture.
When designing the architecture, it is essential to only include components that are necessary to meet the platform’s requirements.

If MySQL + VMs can meet the platform requirements don’t add caching layer like Redis or Memcached to your design. If a database read replica can solve the concurrent bottlenecks, then leave MQ out of the design.

Overcomplicated architecture demands significant development effort, and startups must continually iterate and evolve their product, making any redundant and outdated components in the design problematic. It’s easy to be lured by the latest and greatest advancements in technology, but as a startup, it’s crucial to adopt a practical approach and implement only what is necessary for the business.
The goal should be to achieve the desired outcome in a straightforward manner, rather than attempting to imitate the complex solutions of larger companies.
Don’t admire the cool stuff that Google is doing, implementing something less cool, until you become a Google.

As a tech co-founder in a startup, it is imperative to have a comprehensive understanding of all aspects of the technology, including both AI models and iOS apps. The role of an AI/ML expert extends beyond simply training models, as it requires hands-on involvement in the entire codebase, particularly when working with offshore teams.
To ensure the success of the startup’s technology, it is crucial to eliminate any blind spots in the codebase, which could lead to disastrous consequences in the future.
To achieve this, the tech co-founder need to:

As a leader, it is essential to prioritize both building and managing a team effectively. A team’s success is dependent on not just having skilled engineers, but also having a well-defined workflow, development process, clear objectives, effective leadership, and a motivating incentive structure. Neglecting these elements can result in disorganization and ultimately, failure.
The first lesson I have learned as a tech lead is that having just enough developers is preferable to having an excessive number.
The requirements are coming every hour and every day, I need more developers to accomplish the tasks so that we can deliver more.
The above belief may lead to several challenges, including:
Below are some learnings to address the above problems:

As a CTO, actively engaging with the product is essential to ensure its successful development and delivery. Your role includes determining the most effective use of technology to build the product and ensuring its technical feasibility. Key considerations for this include:

As a CTO, it is important to understand the interdependence between technology, team, and product. Each of these elements plays a crucial role in driving the success of a startup. In order to be effective, it is important to remain passionate and committed to making a positive impact on society through your work.
The critical aspect of technology is to keep it lean and simple, allowing for fast iteration and testing of product hypotheses.

In terms of team management, it is important to prioritize the well-being of team members, network and expand your professional relationships to identify potential talent, and filter out noise to maintain a consistent environment for the team to focus on.

In terms of product development, it is crucial to actively engage with the product team and focus on testing critical assumptions. As a gatekeeper, the CTO must manage stakeholder expectations and ensure that the team is working on the right things that align with the product roadmap and business goals. The process of patenting should also be initiated early, with a focus on generic solutions that are specific enough to be patentable.
Overall, the key takeaway is to continuously balance and integrate technology, team, and product to drive the success of a startup.
As a lifelong learner and technologist, I specialize in the areas of software engineering, machine learning, and cloud engineering.

I bring extensive experience as an engineering and product leader, with a proven track record of defining machine learning strategies, establishing full-stack data science and engineering teams, and delivering end-to-end machine learning solutions at scale.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
